medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Symptoms began at 4 weeks of gestation with an increase in serum free T3 and T4 coinciding with elevated hCG levels. By 6-7 weeks, the patient exhibited hypermetabolic features including mild nausea and vomiting. Peak hormone levels were reached at 12 weeks gestation, followed by a decline and symptom improvement in subsequent weeks. Notable symptoms included anxiety, tremor, tiredness, and palpitations, with no measurements of thyroid function initially taken during her first pregnancy.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Resistance to thyroid hormone (RTH) identified by a mutation in the TR/H9252 gene; previous pregnancies exhibited similar hypermetabolic symptoms.
medical_history.family_history: Family history of RTH; one sister had a large goiter and high free thyroid hormone levels. The father was recently deceased at age 61 and five of eight siblings were also affected by RTH.
